name: sfchronicle
text: Cal Fire is battling a wildland fire just south of Petaluma in Sonoma County. As of 4 p.m., the blaze burned 20 acres and was 0% percent contained. https://t.co/XRTLhE4fL6

name: sfchronicle
text: The coronavirus outbreak and shelter-in-place mandates have shut down campgrounds and lodging across California. RVs may provide vacationers a workaround. https://t.co/K3rcrADR2Y

name: sfchronicle
text: While many cities in the Bay Area have lifted their curfews stemming from protests over police violence, some, such as in Hayward, remain. Here is the list of curfews, plus major service and business closures. The list will continue to be updated.  https://t.co/bKtPfvFOjc https://t.co/7vtI5cnel2

name: sfchronicle
text:
Walnut Creek has ended its curfew, saying it was “no longer needed to help maintain safety in our city.” The announcement followed the conclusion of a demonstration of about 2,000 people. 

Live updates: https://t.co/u0kw3Oc9zK

name: sfchronicle
text: Demonstrators in San Jose created an altar for black people killed by law enforcement, laid just outside San Jose C… https://t.co/d8IAgexfu5

name: sfchronicle
text: Napa County wineries, bars and tasting rooms can reopen as of today, with social distancing guidelines in place. https://t.co/dsGwLVh7Uz

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @ByLHernandez: Hundreds of people are rallying at San Jose City Hall. Passing cars are honking in support, and protesters are chanting, “Black Lives Matter” to the beat of a traditional Mexica dance group. https://t.co/mZJarsazx4Hundreds of people are rallying at San Jose City Hall. Passing cars are honking in support, and protesters are chan… https://t.co/nzHRpMmLUa

name: sfchronicle
text:
NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell said he and the league “were wrong” for ignoring players’ concerns over the growing evidence of police brutality in this country, adding “black lives matter.”

https://t.co/B2UWOjaqfE

name: sfchronicle
text:
The eighth day of protests in the Bay Area brought new cries for justice. In Oakland, there was a call to eliminate the school district police. In S.F., there was outrage over the killing of a local man by Vallejo police. 

https://t.co/X3ZbYE5t4e

name: sfchronicle
text:
LIVE UPDATES: A group of a few hundred protesters is marching from Vallejo City Hall to the Walgreens where 22-year-old Sean Monterrosa was shot and killed by police Tuesday morning.

https://t.co/YtFMDBF7PV

name: sfchronicle
text:
Many CVS and Walgreens locations in the Bay Area remain shuttered after some stores were vandalized and looted. 

Here's a list of the closest open stores for you to fill your prescription (store hours vary by location so call ahead): https://t.co/x5DbN9akbM

name: sfchronicle
text:
When 6 million K-12 students return to school in California, things will be different: 

• Students' temperatures taken every morning
• Teachers should wear face masks, shields
• Desks should be 6 feet apart, separated by partitions or staggered 

https://t.co/2gjgeTBARj

name: sfchronicle
text: See how many cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed in each Bay Area county since the reopening process began >>>  https://t.co/7bD68kwimH https://t.co/BfpooWCTTG

name: sfchronicle
text: Keep up to date with the latest list of Bay Area curfews, plus major service and business closures. The list will continue to be updated. https://t.co/4swJfcX4zR https://t.co/iFJkwHBIFD

name: sfchronicle
text:
SF released guidance on social interactions as the city prepares to reopen:
▪️Outdoor activities are safest
▪️Wear a mask indoors
▪️Avoid using other people's bathrooms
▪️Hang out with as few people as possible
▪️Avoid singing or shouting https://t.co/ZmYxeMmiAi

name: sfchronicle
text:
As protesters face officers outside the Vallejo Police Department, some organizers and family members of Sean Monterrosa want marchers to return downtown. 

“They want blood, we aren’t going to give them blood tonight,” shouted one protester.

https://t.co/LOwkLjUADZ

name: sfchronicle
text: The masks have since been put back in the mail, according to postal officials, but the incident has raised concerns of racial targeting by the print shop’s owner and social justice groups. https://t.co/VwUHHTyy9J

name: sfchronicle
text: White House Press Secretary tweet: “In Contra Costa County, new ‘health’ guidelines allow protests of 100 people, but restrict religious services until June 15. Social distancing should remain data-driven and apolitical: If you can protest, you can pray.” https://t.co/UP0Kj0ukCN

name: sfchronicle
text:
Latest numbers from The Chronicle's Coronavirus Tracker:

– 1,897,239 cases in U.S., 126,255 in California, 15,061 in Bay Area
– 109,127 deaths in U.S., 4,536 in California, 461 in Bay Area

Where does your Bay Area county stand? https://t.co/isufohASmi

https://t.co/e9yCbO6YfB

name: sfchronicle
text:
White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany criticized Contra Costa County's new health guidelines, saying they allow protests but restrict religious services.

County supervisor John Goia shot back, reminding McEnany that the guidelines allow for both.
https://t.co/bXHBxCT80j

name: sfchronicle
text:
After 108 years, St. John the Baptist Catholic School in Napa closed this week. The closure reflects a wider, nationwide trend of private schools struggling to survive the coronavirus crisis.

https://t.co/60Z2Fipm8a

name: sfchronicle
text:
Everyone is adapting to a new lifestyle, including pets. We asked our online readers to share what their animal friends have been up to during this pandemic.

https://t.co/iI55CINoUn

name: sfchronicle
text: Hundreds of protesters gathered around Tommie Smith and John Carlos statue at San Jose State, where both Olympian’s are memorialized raising their fists during the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City. Updates > https://t.co/oLdXYhKPu0 https://t.co/d0eyRFcONh

name: sfchronicle
text:
Films by, about and for black lives: Here’s a list of several must-see movies about the African American struggle for freedom.

https://t.co/1bgTQXUboz

name: sfchronicle
text: Alameda County firefighters extinguished a blaze Friday night that damaged the historic Lorenzo Theatre in San Lorenzo. https://t.co/ZP3cVgjitA

name: sfchronicle
text: California campgrounds, hotels, gyms, bars and museums may reopen as soon as June 12 if they have met safety criteria, under new guidance issued Friday. https://t.co/bYmRN6hSNo

name: sfchronicle
text:
Donations to black-owned Oakland bookstore soar > https://t.co/gciuhGia7E

•  Drinkers supporting black-owned wine businesses. Will it last? asks @Esther_Mobley > https://t.co/dkZkMczByi

•  Black-owned restaurants, pop-ups and caterers in Bay Area > https://t.co/8MRjgR4DrK

name: sfchronicle
text:
K-pop artist and drag princess SOJU, who co-founded the quarterly San Francisco K-pop party Seoul Train, recently tagged Korean music companies in an open letter posted on Twitter, asking hard questions about appropriation.

https://t.co/iiaJW0qBtL
